section.title: Changing Service Passwords
section.para: You can easily change the inter-service passwords used for authenticating communications between services in your HPE Helion cloud deployment, promoting better compliance with your organization’s security policies. The inter-service passwords that can be changed include (but are not limited to) Keystone, MySQL, RabbitMQ, HLM cluster, Monasca and Barbican.
The general process for changing the passwords is to:

listitem.para: Indicate to the configuration processor which password(s) you want to change, and optionally include the value of that password
Run the configuration processor to generate the new passwords (you do not need to run "git add" before this)
Check your password name(s) against the tables included below to see which high-level credentials-change playbook(s) you need to run
Run the appropriate high-level credentials-change playbook(s)

section.para: Encryption passwords supplied to the configuration processor for use with Ansible Vault and for encrypting the configuration processor’s persistent state must have a minimum length of 12 characters and a maximum of 128 characters. Passwords must contain characters from each of the following three categories:

Service Passwords that are automatically generated by the configuration processor are chosen randomly from uppercase, lowercase and numeric characters, with the minimum and maximum lengths being determined by the specific requirements of individual services.

important.para: Currently, you can not use any special characters with Ansible Vault, Service Passwords, or eon/vCenter configuration.

section.bridgehead: Telling the configuration processor which password(s) you want to change
section.para: In , the configuration processor will produce metadata about each of the passwords (and other variables) that it generates in the file ~/helion/my_cloud/info/private_data_metadata.yml. A snippet of this file follows. Expand the header to see the file:

For each variable, there is a metadata entry for each pair of services that use the variable including a list of the clusters on which the service component that consumes the variable (defined as "component:" in private_data_metadata.yml above) runs.
Note above that the variable mysql_admin_password is used by a number of service components, and the service that is consumed in each case is mysql.
First, make sure that you have a copy of private_data_metadata. If you don't, to generate one just run the configuration processor:
Make a copy of the private_data_metadata.yml file and place it into the ~/helion/change_credentials directory:
Edit the copied file in ~/helion/change_credentials leaving only only those passwords you intend to change. All entries in this template file should be deleted except for those passwords.

important.para: If you leave other passwords in that file that you do not want to change, they will be regenerated and no longer match those in use.

note.para: It is required that you change passwords in batches of each category listed below.

section.para: For example, the snippet below would result in the configuration processor generating new random values for keystone_backup_password, keystone_ceilometer_password, and keystone_rgw_password:
section.screen: keystone_backup_password: metadata: - clusters: - cluster0 - cluster1 - compute component: freezer-agent consumes: keystone-api cp: ccp version: '2.0' keystone_ceilometer_password: metadata: - clusters: - cluster1 component: ceilometer-common consumes: keystone-api cp: ccp version: '2.0' keystone_rgw_password: metadata: - clusters: - rgw component: ceph-radosgw consumes: keystone-api cp: cpp version: '2.0'
section.para: Optionally, you can specify a value for the password by including a "value:" key and value at the same level as metadata:
section.screen: keystone_backup_password: value: 'new_password' metadata: - clusters: - cluster0 - cluster1 - compute component: freezer-agent consumes: keystone-api cp: ccp version: '2.0'
section.para: Note that you can have multiple files in helion/change_credentials. The configuration processor will only read files that end in .yml or .yaml.

note.para: If you've specified a password value in your credential change file, you may want to encrypt it using ansible-vault. If you decide to encrypt with ansible-vault, make sure that you use the encryption key you've already used when running the configuration processor.

section.para: To encrypt a file using ansible-vault, execute:
section.screen: stack@padawan-ccp-c0-m1-mgmt:~/helion/change_credentials$ ansible-vault encrypt <credential change file ending in .yml or .yaml>

section.bridgehead: Running the configuration processor to change passwords
section.para: The directory helion/change_credentials is not managed by git, so to rerun the configuration processor to generate new passwords and prepare for the next deployment just enter the following commands:
section.screen: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

note.para: The files that you placed in helion/change_credentials should be removed once you have run the configuration processor because the old password values and new password values will be stored in the configuration processor's persistent state.

Once you've run the configuration processor to change passwords, an information file ~/helion/my_cloud/info/password_change.yml similar to the private_data_metadata.yml is written to tell you which passwords have been changed, including metadata but not including the values.
